content.user_title: Implement iOS Liquid Glass UI effects in SwiftUI
content.value_statement: Creating modern iOS interfaces with Liquid Glass requires understanding Apple's specific APIs and design patterns. This skill provides ready-to-use code patterns and review checklists for implementing glass effects correctly.
actual_capabilities: Implement glassEffect modifier with custom shapes and tints
Create interactive glass elements that respond to touch
Wrap multiple glass elements in GlassEffectContainer
Add morphing transitions using glassEffectID and @Namespace
Apply glass button styles to SwiftUI buttons
Review existing Liquid Glass code for correctness
limitations: Requires iOS 26 or later for Liquid Glass API
Does not provide custom blur implementations
No fallback code generation for older iOS versions

faq.question: Which iOS versions support Liquid Glass?
faq.answer: Liquid Glass requires iOS 26 or later. Always use #available(iOS 26, *) checks and provide fallback materials.

faq.question: What shapes can glassEffect use?
faq.answer: Common shapes include .capsule (default), .rect(cornerRadius: CGFloat), and .circle for custom effects.

faq.question: How do I combine multiple glass elements?
faq.answer: Wrap multiple views in GlassEffectContainer to enable morphing, blending, and proper spacing between effects.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill contains only documentation and code examples. No data is collected, stored, or transmitted.

faq.question: Why is my glass effect not animating?
faq.answer: Ensure you use @Namespace with glassEffectID and wrap view changes in withAnimation for morphing transitions.

faq.question: How is this different from materials?
faq.answer: Liquid Glass offers dynamic blurs, real-time interactivity, and morphing capabilities that standard materials cannot provide.
